channel.title: C+ to c++ then java?
channel.description:
Im trying to see.... I found out thought Java is related to c+ and c++ in a way. Is this formula right:
[s]vb[/s] [>] c+ [>] c++ [>] Java?
I might learn these , especially vb because I just recent discovered that people are looking forward for vb programmers to work for them. Few are interested in Java programmer (only to make more organized programs like cellphones and computers(vb as well))

item.title: C+ to c++ then java?
item.dc:creator: @system system
item.description:
@system wrote:

If I have understood it all correctly, the .NET languages gets compiled into CIL (Common Intermediate Language) (previously known as MSIL (MicroSoft Intermediate Language)) code, which in turn is translated into native code for the CPU to understand.

And the CLR (Common Language Runtime) is the VM (Virtual Machine) for the .NET Framework.

I might be wrong…

Read full topic

item.title: C+ to c++ then java?
item.dc:creator: @chrisn2323 chrisn2323
item.description:
@chrisn2323 wrote:

Silver Lining:

.NET is the same concept as Java’s compiled form (to my knowledge, anyway) so please stop bitching about C# being “single-platform”, dear posters.

I think all .NET gets compiled into the CLR which then gets interpreted like java.

Read full topic

item.title: C+ to c++ then java?
item.dc:creator: @Mopman Mopman
item.description:
@Mopman wrote:

Which is awesome, was it not for the fact that C# is tied in so deeply with .net that using one without a full implementation of the other isn’t practical. Sure, it can be done, but who uses ECMAScript for anything other than Javascript (for example).

In before obscure application written in ECMAScript.

Read full topic

item.title: C+ to c++ then java?
item.dc:creator: @Unhandled Unhandled
item.description:
@Unhandled wrote:

Silver Lining:

.NET is the same concept as Java’s compiled form (to my knowledge, anyway) so please stop bitching about C# being “single-platform”, dear posters.

Alas, some sensible information, from the last person you would expect it from. C# is an open ISO standard, anyone can implement a language compiler on any platform they like. It’s .NET framework library that has some proprietary sections, which is no longer an issue due to the advent of Mono.

Read full topic

item.title: C+ to c++ then java?
item.dc:creator: @zstars zstars
item.description:
@zstars wrote:

[quote=“davidude36, post:31, topic:182509”][quote author=zstars link=topic=244165.msg2064050#msg2064050 date=1203398003]
Some colleges (including mine) seem to like Delphi, for some wicked reason.

[/quote]
Yeah the college I’m going to in September has a course called “Computing” which I’m taking. I was told they mostly program in delphi. There are a lot of people taking it and most of them don’t even know how to use a computer of any sort so I suppose it must be an easy language to grasp for computer newbie’s. Hopefully having the little java experience I have and a full 10 years computing + typing experience it will help me out =D.

btw zstars where are you from?[/quote]

Spain

Delphi is indeed rather easy, but its syntax is fugly, and it has no remarkable features, apart from a serialization system which is curious at first, but ultimately, weak and useless. If you have ever used Scar, you will notice that it is the same language (Pascal), but with Object Oriented additions.

Read full topic

item.title: C+ to c++ then java?
item.dc:creator: @bakatool bakatool
item.description:
@bakatool wrote:

first of all u gotta learn the basics of programming thats why everyone starts from

Visual Basic! to get the feel of programming then.
move to something still easy but simple go to
C#
Well could try java too its just as simple
C++ is similar to java but u gotta think mathematically and wayy to much rules to follow but ull get there.

if u want something done fast do it in whatever langauge you feel comfortable with.
If you are forced to use C++ for like making base hooks then you are forced to use it and you gotta learn it no matter what but having basics down like if statment for loops whiles switches all that will give you advantage of everyone else who just starts with those HELLO worlds you could jump right into it and start coding. Learning assembly is also a must if u wanna debug your program later using pdbs

Read full topic

item.title: C+ to c++ then java?
item.dc:creator: @Mopman Mopman
item.description:
@Mopman wrote:

[quote=“Javacisnotrecognized, post:22, topic:182509”][quote author=Moparisthebest link=topic=244165.msg2064598#msg2064598 date=1203417991]
And I could write a compiler to compile it to native Linux code as well.

C# is only supported on and is intended for windows, the mono project aims to make it cross platform, but Microsoft certainly doesn’t want that.
[/quote]

Sure, Microsoft wouldn’t want their framework to become a viable tool for developing cross platform programs.

I mean that would be crazy, right?[/quote]

Microsoft thrive on OS lockin. They love it. Just look at DirectX 10.

Read full topic

item.title: C+ to c++ then java?
item.dc:creator: @qauters qauters
item.description:
@qauters wrote:

[quote=“Javacisnotrecognized, post:22, topic:182509”][quote author=Moparisthebest link=topic=244165.msg2064598#msg2064598 date=1203417991]
And I could write a compiler to compile it to native Linux code as well.

C# is only supported on and is intended for windows, the mono project aims to make it cross platform, but Microsoft certainly doesn’t want that.
[/quote]

Sure, Microsoft wouldn’t want their framework to become a viable tool for developing cross platform programs.

I mean that would be crazy, right?[/quote]
Ofcourse, because they want people to buy Windows instead of Linux.

Today’s main languages are C++, C#.Net and Java. Only if you want to program for mac you need to learn C objective.
These languages look a lot like each other, except you need to learn to work with pointers etc in C++.
They all have great things in it.
C++ for it’s speed and being native, so you can’t decompile (except to assembly) etc.
C# for it’s library. It’s doesn’t cost to much time to create a good program in C#.
Java for being cross platform. Mainly used in web applications/firmware.

Read full topic

item.description:
@Mopman wrote:

zstars:

(That is, if both a C and a C++ compiler are available)

That’s just it. Many platforms do not have a decent C++ compiler available (think embedded shit).

Read full topic

item.title: C+ to c++ then java?
item.dc:creator: @zstars zstars
item.description:
@zstars wrote:

Some colleges (including mine) seem to like Delphi, for some wicked reason. Personally I don’t like it, ugly syntax, no remarkable features, and fully propietary.

BTW note that when I say that C is outdated, I am not saying that it is not used. Even Assembler is still used nowadays. However, to my knowledge, today there is no reason to, if given the choice (That is, if both a C and a C++ compiler are available), choose to start a new project in C over C++. C++ was designed to be backwards compatible with C. There is nothing ISO C can do, that ISO C++ can’t. But obviously, that doesn’t work the other way round.

Read full topic

item.title: C+ to c++ then java?
item.dc:creator: @Unhandled Unhandled
item.description:
@Unhandled wrote:

Moparisthebest:

C isn’t exactly outdated, drivers and operating system kernels are still written in it.

Don’t forget portable devices, like the PSP, and if you ever want to develop the Linux kernel, you’ll be coding in C. If C# wasn’t made my microsoft, I’m sure a hell of a lot more people would like it.

Read full topic

item.title: C+ to c++ then java?
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

C isn’t exactly outdated, drivers and operating system kernels are still written in it. If you want a job it would be good to have experience in Java, C++, C and (as bad as I hate to admit it) some .net languages

Most jobs I have seen however ask for Java or C++ experience.

Read full topic
